name: Example Lipid Profile
description: Describes how the lab report is used for a standard Lipid Profile - Cholesterol, Triglyceride and Cholesterol fractions. Uses LOINC codes

definition.formal: The findings and interpretation of a general lipd lab profile.
definition.comments: In this profile, mustSupport means that authoring systems must include the ability to report these elements, and processing systems must cater for them by either displaying them to the user or considering them appropriately in decision support systems.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
definition.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

definition.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
definition.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
definition.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

definition.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
definition.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

definition.short: LOINC Code for Lipid Panel with LDL
definition.formal: LOINC Code for Lipid Panel with LDL.
definition.comments: LOINC code includes "direct" LDL - does this mean LDL derived by measuring VLDL by ultracentrifugation? This panel includes both measured and calculated LDL.

binding.name: DiagnosticReportNames
binding.description: Codes that describe Diagnostic Reports

mapping.map: OBR-4-Universal Service ID (V2 doesn't provide an easy way to indicate both the ordered test and the performed panel)

definition.formal: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole.
definition.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications need to take appropriate action if a report is withdrawn.

binding.name: DiagnosticReportStatus
binding.description: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole

mapping.map:
statusCode

Note: final and amended are distinguished by whether observation is the subject of a ControlAct event of type "revise"

definition.formal: The date and/or time that this version of the report was released from the source diagnostic service.
definition.comments: May be different from the update time of the resource itself, because that is the status of the record (potentially a secondary copy), not the actual release time of the report.

definition.short: The subject of the report, usually, but not always, the patient
definition.formal: The subject of the report. Usually, but not always, this is a patient. However diagnostic services also perform analyses on specimens collected from a variety of other sources.

mapping.map: PID-3-Patient ID List (no V2 mapping for Group or Device)

definition.formal: The diagnostic service that is responsible for issuing the report.
definition.comments: This is not necessarily the source of the atomic data items - it is the entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.

definition.short: Id for external references to this report
definition.formal: The local ID assigned to the report by the order filler, usually by the Information System of the diagnostic service provider.

mapping.map: OBR-51-Observation Group ID (todo: check semantic intent of OBR-51 with OOWG)

definition.formal: Details concerning a test requested.
definition.comments: Note: Usually there is one test request for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single test result resource. Note that there are also cases where one request leads to multiple reports.

definition.formal: The section of the diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, hematology, MRI.

binding.name: DiagnosticServiceSection
binding.description: Codes for diagnostic service sections

definition.formal: The time or time-period the observed values are related to. This is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection(s), but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
definition.comments: If the diagnostic procedure was performed on the patient, this is the time it was performed. If there are specimens, the diagnostically relevant time can be derived from the specimen collection times, but the specimen information is not always available, and the exact relationship between the specimens and the diagnostically relevant time is not always automatic.

definition.short: Specimens this report is based on
definition.formal: Details about the specimens on which this Disagnostic report is based.
definition.comments: If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data may be redundant. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per Observation or group.

definition.short: Observations - simple, or complex nested groups
definition.formal: Observations that are part of this diagnostic report. Observations can be simple name/value pairs (e.g. "atomic" results), or they can be grouping observations that include references to other members of the group (e.g. "panels").
Reference to Cholesterol Result.
Group of elements for Triglyceride result.
Group of elements for HDL Cholesterol result.
LDL Cholesterol result, if reported.

definition.short: Reference to full details of imaging associated with the diagnostic report
definition.formal: One or more links to full details of any imaging performed during the diagnostic investigation. Typically, this is imaging performed by DICOM enabled modalities, but this is not required. A fully enabled PACS viewer can use this information to provide views of the source images.
definition.comments: ImagingStudy and image are somewhat overlapping - typically, an image in the image list will also be found in the imaging study resource. However the imaging study and image lists cater to different types of displays for different types of purposes. Neither, either, or both may be provided.

definition.short: Key images associated with this report
definition.formal: A list of key images associated with this report. The images are generally created during the diagnostic process, and may be directly of the patient, or of treated specimens (i.e. slides of interest).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: A comment about the image. Typically, this is used to provide an explanation for why the image is included, or to draw the viewer's attention to important features.
definition.comments: The comment should be displayed with the image. It would be common for the report to include additional discussion of the image contents in other sections such as the conclusion.

definition.formal: Reference to the image source.
May include diagnosis or suggestions for follow up testing.
definition.comments: It's not unusual for the lab to make some kind of interpretative comment on the set of results.

definition.short: No codes for a lipid panel
definition.formal: No codes for a lipid panel.
definition.comments: Not used in this context.

binding.name: AdjunctDiagnosis
binding.description: Diagnoses codes provided as adjuncts to the report

definition.formal: Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they SHALL be semantically equivalent.
definition.comments: Application/pdf is recommended as the most reliable and interoperable in this context.

definition.formal: The findings and interpretation of a general lipd lab profile.
definition.comments: In this profile, mustSupport means that authoring systems must include the ability to report these elements, and processing systems must cater for them by either displaying them to the user or considering them appropriately in decision support systems.

definition.short: LOINC Code for Lipid Panel with LDL
definition.formal: LOINC Code for Lipid Panel with LDL.
definition.comments: LOINC code includes "direct" LDL - does this mean LDL derived by measuring VLDL by ultracentrifugation? This panel includes both measured and calculated LDL.

definition.formal: Reference to Cholesterol Result.
Group of elements for Triglyceride result.
Group of elements for HDL Cholesterol result.
LDL Cholesterol result, if reported.
May include diagnosis or suggestions for follow up testing.
definition.comments: It's not unusual for the lab to make some kind of interpretative comment on the set of results.

definition.short: No codes for a lipid panel
definition.formal: No codes for a lipid panel.
definition.comments: Not used in this context.

definition.formal: Measurements and simple assertions made about a patient, device or other subject.
definition.comments: Used for simple observations such as device measurements, laboratory atomic results, vital signs, height, weight, smoking status, comments, etc.  Other resources are used to provide context for observations such as Lab reports, etc.

constraint.name: reference range for quantity
constraint.human: Can only have normal range if value is a quantity

definition.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. definition.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.

definition.formal: Cholesterol.

binding.name: ObservationType
binding.description: Codes identifying types of simple observations

definition.formal: The information determined as a result of making the observation, if the information has a simple value.
definition.comments: Normally, an observation will have either a value or a set of related observations. A few observations (e.g. apgar store) may have both a value and related observations (for apgar, the observations from which the measure is derived). If a value is present, the datatype for this element should be determined by Observation.name. A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Observation.name defines a coded value. The element, Observation.value[x], has a variable name depending on the type as follows: valueQuantity, valueCodeableConcept, valueRatio, valueChoice, valuePeriod, valueSampleData, or valueString (The name format is "'value' + the type name" with a capital on the first letter of the type).

binding.name: ObservationInterpretation
binding.description: Codes identifying interpretations of observations

definition.formal: May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable. values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.

mapping.map: NTE.3 (partner NTE to OBX, or sometimes another (child?) OBX)

definition.formal: The time or time-period the observed value is asserted as being true. For biological subjects - e.g. human patients - this is usually called the "physiologically relevant time". This is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection, but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
definition.comments: At least a date should be present unless this observation is a historical report.

mapping.map: OBX-14-date/time of the observation, and/or OBX-19 after v2.4  (depends on who observation made)

definition.formal: Date/Time this was made available.
definition.comments: Updated when the result is updated.

mapping.map: OBR.22 (or MSH.7), or perhaps OBX-19 (depends on who observation made)

definition.formal: The status of the result value.

binding.name: ObservationStatus
binding.description: Codes providing the status of an observation

mapping.map:
status

Amended & Final are differentiated by whether it is the subject of a ControlAct event with a type of "revise"

definition.short: Cholesterol values can only be reported when there is no question about their status.
definition.formal: Cholesterol values can only be reported when there is no question about their status.
definition.comments: Note that in most contexts, unreliable results are not recorded, deleted, or otherwise excluded, but it's not always possible to exclude them from the record. Interpreters of a result, whether human or machine, SHALL always either be aware of the status, or prevented from using the observation without being unaware that the reliability is not "ok".

binding.name: ObservationReliability
binding.description: Codes that provide an estimate of the degree to which quality issues have impacted on the value of an observation

definition.formal: Indicates where on the subject's body the observation was made.
definition.comments: Only used if not implicit in code found in Observation.name.

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality

definition.formal: Indicates the mechanism used to perform the observation.
definition.comments: Only used if not implicit in code for Observation.name.

binding.name: ObservationMethod
binding.description: Methods for simple observations

definition.short: Unique Id for this particular observation
definition.formal: A unique identifier for the simple observation.

definition.short: Who and/or what this is about
definition.formal: The thing the observation is being made about.
definition.comments: The only circumstance in which the subject can be missing is when the observation is made by a device that does not know the patient. In this case, the observation SHALL be matched to a patient through some context/channel matching technique, and at this point, the observation should be updated.

definition.formal: The specimen that was used when this observation was made.
definition.comments: Observations are not made on specimens themselves; they are made on a subject, but usually by the means of a specimen. Note that although specimens are often involved, they are not always tracked and reported explicitly. Also note that observation resources are often used in contexts that track the specimen explicity (e.g. Diagnostic Report).

definition.formal: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".
definition.comments: This would only be "Device" if the device is responsible for the measurement, not to capture the device used by a human to make the measurement.  (The latter could be captured as an extension.).

mapping.map:
OBX.15 / (Practitioner)  OBX-16-responsible observer,  PRT-5-participation person:PRT-4-participation='RO' / 
(Device)  OBX-18-equipment instance identifier , PRT-10-participation device:PRT-4-participation='EQUIP' / (Organization)  OBX-23-performing organization name,  PRT-8-participation organization:PRT-4-participation='PO'

definition.formal: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.
definition.comments: Most observations only have one generic reference range. Systems MAY choose to restrict to only supplying the relevant reference range based on knowledge about the patient (e.g. specific to the patient's age, gender, weight and other factors), but this may not be possible or appropriate. Whenever more than one reference range is supplied, the differences between them SHOULD be provided in the reference range and/or age properties.

constraint.name: reference range
constraint.human: Must have at least a low or a high (and no comparators) or text
constraint.xpath: (exists(f:low) or exists(f:high)or exists(f:text)) and not(exists(f:low/f:comparator)) and not(exists(f:high/f:comparator))

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. definition.formal: The value of the low bound of the reference range. If this is omitted, the low bound of the reference range is assumed to be meaningless. E.g. <2.3.
definition.comments: Do not use the comparator for < or >.

definition.formal: <4.5 mmol/L.
definition.comments: Per Australian NHF Recommendations.

definition.formal: Range is a recommended range.
definition.comments: This SHOULD be populated if there is more than one range.

binding.name: ObservationRangeMeaning
binding.description: Code for the meaning of a reference range

definition.formal: The age at which this reference range is applicable. This is a neonatal age (e.g. number of weeks at term) if the meaning says so.

definition.short: Text based reference range in an observation
definition.formal: Text based reference range in an observation which may be used when a quantitative range is not appropriate for an observation.  An example would be a reference value of "Negative" or a list or table of 'normals'.
Related observations - either components, or previous observations, or statements of derivation.
definition.comments: Normally, an observation will have either a value or a set of related observations. A few observations (e.g. apgar store) may have both a value and related observations (for apgar, the observations from which the measure is derived).

definition.short: has-component | has-member | derived-from | sequel-to | replaces | qualified-by | interfered-by
definition.formal: A code specifying the kind of relationship that exists with the target observation.
definition.comments: A relationship type SHOULD be provided. If the relationship type is "COMP" (composed), then the observation should not be displayed/interpreted in the absence of the related observations.

binding.name: ObservationRelationshipType
binding.description: Codes specifying how two observations are related

definition.short: Observation that is related to this one
definition.formal: A reference to the observation that is related to this observation.
Cholesterol.
Cholesterol value. If a result is not available, use the comments field.
Actual numerical value.

definition.comments: No need for this on cholesterol.

definition.formal: May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable. values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.

definition.comments: This would only be "Device" if the device is responsible for the measurement, not to capture the device used by a human to make the measurement.  (The latter could be captured as an extension.).

mapping.map:
OBX.15 / (Practitioner)  OBX-16-responsible observer,  PRT-5-participation person:PRT-4-participation='RO' / 
(Device)  OBX-18-equipment instance identifier , PRT-10-participation device:PRT-4-participation='EQUIP' / (Organization)  OBX-23-performing organization name,  PRT-8-participation organization:PRT-4-participation='PO'

definition.formal: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.
definition.comments: Most observations only have one generic reference range. Systems MAY choose to restrict to only supplying the relevant reference range based on knowledge about the patient (e.g. specific to the patient's age, gender, weight and other factors), but this may not be possible or appropriate. Whenever more than one reference range is supplied, the differences between them SHOULD be provided in the reference range and/or age properties.

constraint.name: reference range
constraint.human: Must have at least a low or a high (and no comparators) or text
constraint.xpath: (exists(f:low) or exists(f:high)or exists(f:text)) and not(exists(f:low/f:comparator)) and not(exists(f:high/f:comparator))

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. definition.formal: The value of the low bound of the reference range. If this is omitted, the low bound of the reference range is assumed to be meaningless. E.g. <2.3.
definition.comments: Do not use the comparator for < or >.

definition.formal: The value of the high bound of the reference range. If this is omitted, the high bound of the reference range is assumed to be meaningless. E.g. >5.
definition.comments: Per Australian NHF Recommendations.

definition.formal: Range is a recommended range.
definition.comments: This SHOULD be populated if there is more than one range.

binding.name: ObservationRangeMeaning

definition.formal: The age at which this reference range is applicable. This is a neonatal age (e.g. number of weeks at term) if the meaning says so.

definition.short: Text based reference range in an observation
definition.formal: Text based reference range in an observation which may be used when a quantitative range is not appropriate for an observation.  An example would be a reference value of "Negative" or a list or table of 'normals'.
Related observations - either components, or previous observations, or statements of derivation.
definition.comments: Normally, an observation will have either a value or a set of related observations. A few observations (e.g. apgar store) may have both a value and related observations (for apgar, the observations from which the measure is derived).

definition.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
definition.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

definition.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
definition.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
definition.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

definition.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
definition.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

definition.formal: HDL Cholesterol.

binding.name: ObservationType
binding.description: Codes identifying types of simple observations

definition.formal: HDL Cholesterol value. If a result is not available, use the comments field.
definition.comments: Normally, an observation will have either a value or a set of related observations. A few observations (e.g. apgar store) may have both a value and related observations (for apgar, the observations from which the measure is derived). If a value is present, the datatype for this element should be determined by Observation.name. A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Observation.name defines a coded value. The element, Observation.value[x], has a variable name depending on the type as follows: valueQuantity, valueCodeableConcept, valueRatio, valueChoice, valuePeriod, valueSampleData, or valueString (The name format is "'value' + the type name" with a capital on the first letter of the type).

binding.name: ObservationInterpretation
binding.description: Codes identifying interpretations of observations

definition.formal: Comments about result.

mapping.map: NTE.3 (partner NTE to OBX, or sometimes another (child?) OBX)

definition.formal: The time or time-period the observed value is asserted as being true. For biological subjects - e.g. human patients - this is usually called the "physiologically relevant time". This is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection, but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
definition.comments: At least a date should be present unless this observation is a historical report.

mapping.map: OBX-14-date/time of the observation, and/or OBX-19 after v2.4  (depends on who observation made)

definition.formal: Date/Time this was made available.
definition.comments: Updated when the result is updated.

mapping.map: OBR.22 (or MSH.7), or perhaps OBX-19 (depends on who observation made)

definition.formal: The status of the result value.

binding.name: ObservationStatus
binding.description: Codes providing the status of an observation

mapping.map:
status

Amended & Final are differentiated by whether it is the subject of a ControlAct event with a type of "revise"

definition.short: ok | ongoing | early | questionable | calibrating | error +
definition.formal: An estimate of the degree to which quality issues have impacted on the value reported.
definition.comments: Note that in most contexts, unreliable results are not recorded, deleted, or otherwise excluded, but it's not always possible to exclude them from the record. Interpreters of a result, whether human or machine, SHALL always either be aware of the status, or prevented from using the observation without being unaware that the reliability is not "ok".

binding.name: ObservationReliability
binding.description: Codes that provide an estimate of the degree to which quality issues have impacted on the value of an observation

definition.formal: Indicates where on the subject's body the observation was made.
definition.comments: Only used if not implicit in code found in Observation.name.

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality

definition.formal: Indicates the mechanism used to perform the observation.
definition.comments: Only used if not implicit in code for Observation.name.

binding.name: ObservationMethod
binding.description: Methods for simple observations

definition.short: Unique Id for this particular observation
definition.formal: A unique identifier for the simple observation.

definition.short: Who and/or what this is about
definition.formal: The thing the observation is being made about.
definition.comments: The only circumstance in which the subject can be missing is when the observation is made by a device that does not know the patient. In this case, the observation SHALL be matched to a patient through some context/channel matching technique, and at this point, the observation should be updated.

definition.formal: The specimen that was used when this observation was made.
definition.comments: Observations are not made on specimens themselves; they are made on a subject, but usually by the means of a specimen. Note that although specimens are often involved, they are not always tracked and reported explicitly. Also note that observation resources are often used in contexts that track the specimen explicity (e.g. Diagnostic Report).

definition.formal: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".
definition.comments: This would only be "Device" if the device is responsible for the measurement, not to capture the device used by a human to make the measurement.  (The latter could be captured as an extension.).

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

definition.short: has-component | has-member | derived-from | sequel-to | replaces | qualified-by | interfered-by
definition.formal: A code specifying the kind of relationship that exists with the target observation.
definition.comments: A relationship type SHOULD be provided. If the relationship type is "COMP" (composed), then the observation should not be displayed/interpreted in the absence of the related observations.

binding.name: ObservationRelationshipType
binding.description: Codes specifying how two observations are related

definition.short: Observation that is related to this one
definition.formal: A reference to the observation that is related to this observation.
Group of elements for LDL Cholesterol result.
Whether LDL value is calculated.

definition.short: LDL Cholesterol -measured or calculated per code
definition.formal: LDL Cholesterol -measured or calculated per code.
LDL Cholesterol value. If a result is not available, use the comments field.

<3.0 mmol/L.
definition.comments: Per Australian NHF Recommendations.

definition.formal: Range is a recommended range.
True if the LDL value is calculated from Chol, Trig, and HDLC.
definition.comments: It's definitely better that whether the LDL was calculated or not comes from the LOINC code. But this is defined to exercise the extension machinery in the publication tooling, and to make this comment. Actually, the location is odd too - it would probably be on the root observation, but this is for testing purposes.
